headline.seo: Obama Concedes That Courts Can Review Acts of Congress
headline.print_headline: Administration Tells a Court It Doesn’t Deny Its Powers

docs.abstract: Obama administration backpedals after federal appeals court demands that the administration explain the president's remarks about the Supreme Court's review of the health care overhaul.

byline.original: By DAVID DE FERRANTI and JULIO FRENK

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on March 29 about the varied opinions among Americans about the individual mandate -- the central provision of the Affordable Care Act that requires most Americans to obtain health insurance -- referred incorrectly to a medical student in San Diego who commented on the possibility that the Supreme Court might strike down the law. The student, Rohan Vilms, is a man.

docs.lead_paragraph: The charge of judicial activism that has long motivated Republican voters could become useful for Democrats, strategists in both parties suggest.

headline.seo: This Election, Supreme Court Could Rally Democrats
headline.main: Court’s Potential to Goad Voters Swings to Democrats
headline.print_headline: Court’s Potential to Goad Voters Swings to Democrats

docs.abstract: Some political strategists suggest that Pres Obama may be able to use the threat of Supreme Court activism, specifically in its Constitutional review of the Affordable Care Act, as an issue to rally his base in the 2012 election; judicial activism has traditionally been used to mobilize conservative voters.
docs.snippet: The charge of judicial activism that has long motivated Republican voters could become useful for Democrats, strategists in both parties suggest.

docs.lead_paragraph: The F.T.C. just approved a $29 billion merger of Express Scripts and Medco, but competition among pharmacy benefit managers appears to be alive and well.

headline.seo: Costs, Benefits and Your Prescription Plan
headline.main: Costs, Benefits and Your Drug Plan
headline.print_headline: Costs, Benefits and Your Drug Plan

docs.abstract: Editorial supports decision by the Federal Trade Commission to approve the merger between Express Scripts and Medco Health Solutions, two of the three largest companies that manage pharmaceutical benefits for employers and health plans; cites FTC's thorough eight-month inquiry as well as the growing number of competitors to the major providers.
docs.snippet: The F.T.C. just approved a $29 billion merger of Express Scripts and Medco, but competition among pharmacy benefit managers appears to be alive and well.
